title: The role of E-cadherin mediated cell-cell contact in melanocyte homeostasis
abstractText: Background Melanocytes are highly specialised cells within the skin, where they act as a protective shield against harmful UV rays in a process called the tanning response. Melanocytes are part of the Epidermal Melanin Unit, in which each melanocyte exists in a symbiotic relationship with ca. 36 keratinocytes at the basement membrane of the epidermis. Sun exposure triggers the production of the pigment melanin within the melanocytes, and this melanin is transferred to the surrounding mitotically active keratinocytes in order to protect them from UV induced DNA damage. On the other hand keratinocytes secrete factors that control the survival, differentiation and growth of melanocytes in response to UV radiation. In fact keratinocytes are mainly responsible for the regulation of melanocyte homeostasis and they ensure that melanocytes stay localised within the Epidermal Melanin Unit and that differentiation is favoured over proliferation. In order to function within this symbiotic relationship an accurate communication between melanocytes and keratinocytes is absolutely essential and direct cell-cell contact is a prerequisite for this communication. At the molecular level the major mediators of cell-cell contacts are cadherins and they regulate cellular functions through multi-protein complexes. Any disturbance of the melanocyte-keratinocyte interaction, and this means the controlled contact between these two cell types, can create a pathological situation. The best-known example for such a situation is the loss of the cell-cell contact protein E-cadherin in melanocytes. This loss results in deregulated melanocyte proliferation and contributes to the transformation into malignant melanoma, the most deadly form of skin cancer. Challenge Elucidating the mechanisms regulating the concerted actions between melanocytes and keratinocytes under physiological conditions will allow to identify dysregulations in pathological situations. Therefore it is important to fully comprehend how cell-cell contact with keratinocytes contributes to the regulation of melanocyte homeostatsis. The main focus in the investigation of melanocyte regulation over the past years has been on the direct effects of keratinocyte-derived growth and differentiation factors on melanocyte monocultures. This does not reflect the physiological situation in which melanocytes adhere to keratinocytes via E-cadherin during growth-factor exposure. Therefore more complex cell systems are required to accurately investigate keratinocyte-mediated regulation of melanocyte function. In addition, although E-cadherin is known to be critical for the malignant transformation of melanocytes, the function and regulation of E-cadherin and its associated proteins in melanocytes is greatly unknown. Approach This project will identify cell-cell contact dependent effects on melanocyte homeostasis within a system that closely recapitulates the human tissue. I will set up a melanocyte-keratinocyte co-culture system, in which melanocytes will be exposed to keratinocyte-derived factors in the context of cell-cell contact to keratinocytes. A technique will be applied that allows monitoring the formation of E-cadherin complexes in the cell-cell contacts. By manipulating the cells (e.g. using specific inhibitors of cellular signalling networks), the molecular signals involved in the regulation of E-cadherin complexes will be identified. Furthermore, the function of E-cadherin in melanocyte homeostasis will be dissected by analysing cellular signalling activities in melanocytes after E-cadherin depletion. This approach will allow uncovering the molecular basis of important control mechanisms in a physiological context. These mechanisms are often lost in the case of disease. Understanding the molecular basis will help to efficiently interfere with a pathological situation and to design drugs that can restore the lost control, ultimately helping to cure the patient.
findingsText:
Cadherin mediated cell-cell adhesions are essential in maintaining tissue integrity, and as such membrane localised E-cadherin is believed to be responsible for the controlled communication between the pigment cells (melanocytes) and keratinocytes in the epidermal layer of the skin. The interactions between melanocytes and keratinocytes regulate melanocyte homeostasis, but this regulation is disturbed in pathological situations such as melanoma skin cancer. It is known that E-cadherin expression is down-regulated during initial steps of melanocyte transformation and melanoma development. However the role of E-cadherin in melanocyte homeostasis and the consequences of reduced E-cadherin function on melanocytes in the skin is unclear.

We have established a co-culture system that allowed us to dissect the contribution of E-cadherin mediated signalling to the homeostasis of melanocytes in the skin. We found that reducing the amount of E-cadherin expression in melanocytes increased their proliferation in response to growth factors. It also led to enhanced melanocyte migration, which otherwise was restrained by the melanocyte-keratinocyte interactions. These findings are in line with an established model of E-cadherin loss resulting in an increase in unbound E-cadherin core-complex components that contribute to proliferation and migration.



The analysis of E-cadherin complex components revealed that beta-catenin, a known regulator of epithelial cell transformation, was not contributing to these increased activities. In melanocytic cells, the increase in E-cadherin unbound beta-catenin resulted in strong up-regulation of the transcription factor MITF, which suppressed proliferative and migratory activities.



Surprisingly, the proliferation and migration in the absence of E-cadherin required p120-catenin. When we microscopically monitored the formation of E-cadherin/p120-catenin interactions, we found that the stimulation of melanocytes by growth factors (bFGF) increased the turnover of the cadherin/catenin complex at the membrane. This led to an increase in cytoplasmic p120-catenin, which regulates proliferation via suppression of the cell cycle inhibitor p21Cip. Likewise the stimulation with motility factors (HGF) increased the amount of cytoplasmic p120-catenin, which stimulates migration presumably through PI3-kinase signalling.



A follow up analysis in melanoma cells revealed that p120-catenin is required for melanoma cell proliferation and migration/invasion. Because many melanoma cells display significantly reduced E-cadherin expression, the contribution of p120-catenin to these melanoma cell activities was more pronounced than in melanocytes. Interestingly, melanoma cells that maintain E-cadherin expression show deregulation at the level of either trafficking or endocytosis, which results in loss of membrane localisation of the cadherin allowing cytoplasmic p120-catenin to prevail.



Our findings are intriguing, because in epithelial cells p120-catenin is required to stabilise E-cadherin and both E-cadherin and p120-catenin are considered tumour suppressor. On the other hand, beta-catenin is considered a tumour promoter and oncogene in epithelial cancers and we found that it suppresses migration and invasion in melanocytic cells.



In summary, we have discovered an important difference in the role and regulation of cadherin/catenin signalling in melanocytic cells (which are of neural crest origin) and epithelial cells. These findings can have implications for the diagnosis of melanoma with regard to using cadherins and catenins as predictive markers. The findings of our research can contribute to the improvement of melanoma diagnosis, because they reveal a specific feature correlated with melanoma progression that differs from other cancer types.



Further dissection of the mechanisms that our research revealed might allow the improvement of current targeted therapies in place for melanoma. Healthcare,Pharmaceuticals and Medical Biotechnology
